text: Sigurd Wettenhovi-Aspa (1940). Georg Sigurd Wettenhovi-Aspa (born. Wetterhoff- Asp, 7 May 1870 – 18 February 1946) was a Finnish multiartist: painter, sculptor, writer, and a pseudo-linguist. He is best known for his fantastic theories about the past of the Finnish people, whom he believed to have descended from Ancient Egypt. Born in Helsinki, his parents were Georg August Asp (1834–1901), professor of anatomy at the University of Helsinki and Mathilda Sofia Wetterhoff (1840–1920), developer of female gymnastics. Wettenhovi-Aspa studied art in Copenhagen in the Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts from 1888 to 1891.Suomen kuvataiteilijat - WETTENHOVI-ASPA (ent. Wetterhoff-Asp) Georg SIGURD - ryhmänäyttelyt He organized several art shows known as the Free Exhibitions. He died in Helsinki. == References == Category:1870 births Category:1946 deaths Category:Artists from Helsinki Category:People from Uusimaa Province (Grand Duchy of Finland) Category:Swedish-speaking Finns Category:Finnish Freemasons Category:19th- century Finnish painters Category:20th-century Finnish painters Category:Finnish architects Category:Linguists from Finland Category:Finnish Egyptologists Category:Finnish composers Category:Finnish male composers Category:19th-century Finnish poets Category:20th-century Finnish poets Category:Finnish eugenicists Category:Finnish inventors Category:Fennomans Category:Utopists Category:Finnish male poets Category:20th-century male writers Category:20th-century Finnish sculptors Category:19th-century Finnish sculptors
title: Sigurd Wettenhovi-Aspa
